Hank_Flamingo:
{{short description|American country music group}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Hank Flamingo | image = Hank Flamingo.jpg | caption = Hank Flamingo, 1994 | image_size = | origin = [[Lascassas, Tennessee]], United States | genre = [[country music|Country]] | years_active = 1988â€“1994 | label = [[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant]] | past_members = Eddie Grigg
Ben Northern
Stuart E. Stuart
Trent Summar
Philip Wallace
Roy Watts }} '''Hank Flamingo''' was an American [[country music]] band founded in the late 1980s. Its membership comprised Trent Summar ([[lead vocals]]), Philip Wallace ([[guitar]]), Eddie Grigg (guitar, vocals), Ben Northern ([[bass guitar]], vocals), Stuart E. Stuart ([[fiddle]], vocals), and Roy Watts ([[Drum kit|drums]]).{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p142880|pure_url=yes}} |title=Hank Flamingo Biography |accessdate=2007-12-25 |last=Bush |first=John |work=Allmusic}} The band recorded one major-label studio album in 1994, before disbanding not long afterward. By 2000, frontman Trent Summar founded another group called [[Trent Summar & The New Row Mob]], in which former Hank Flamingo guitarist Philip Wallace was also a member. ==Biography== Hank Flamingo was founded in 1989 in the state of [[Tennessee]]. Lead vocalist Trent Summar and his friend Eddie Grigg owned a [[farmhouse]] in [[Lascassas, Tennessee]], where they began working on music together. They began working with other musicians until they decided to form a band. The band's name originated when a friend of Summar's gave him a [[plastic flamingo]] as a gift, which he mounted inside the farmhouse next to a portrait of [[Hank Williams]].{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/496800550/ | title=Honest, downhome, and crazy | work=[[The Leader-Post]] | date=July 11, 1994 | accessdate=May 30, 2022 | pages=C3}} By 1993, they were signed to a recording contract with [[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant Records Nashville]], who released the band's eponymous debut album the following year. Hank Flamingo made an appearance on the talk show ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' to promote their album.{{cite web |url= {{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p129608|pure_url=yes}} |title=Trent Summar biography |accessdate=2007-12-25 |last=Johnson |first=Zac |work=[[Allmusic]]}} Included on the disc was a cover of [[George Jones]]' "[[White Lightning (The Big Bopper song)|White Lightning]]", along with songs written by [[John Hiatt]] and former [[NRBQ]] member [[Al Anderson (NRBQ)|Al Anderson]]. "Baby It's You" was the album's lead single.{{cite journal | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-RandR/1990s/1994/RR-1994-01-07.pdf | title=Flamingo Debut Takes Flight | journal=[[Radio & Records]] | pages=34 | date=January 7, 1994}} Writing about the band in ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', Melinda Newman stated that " This new sextet comes on like a cross between [[Webb Wilder]] and [[the Georgia Satellites]]...Much of this release is way too quirky for country radio, but cuts such as 'Redneck Martians Stole My Baby' should make inroads at college and wacky alternative outlets."{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Billboard-Index/IDX/1993/1993-07-31-Billboard-Page-0012.pdf | title=Upcoming Releases Rise To The Top; Garth Sparks Barbecues & Boycotts | author=Melinda Newman | magazine=Billboard | pages=12 | date=July 31, 1993}} A review in the same magazine was mixed, stating that it "caters to new country audience by combining country and alternative rock. Unfortunately, the record is devoid of any surprises."{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1994/BB-1994-02-19.pdf | title=Reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=56 | date=February 19, 1994}} Susan Beyer of ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]'' was more positive, praising the band's sense of humor and "controlled thrashing" of their playing, although she criticized the slower songs on the album.{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/464855779/ | title=Country | work=The Ottawa Citizen | date=March 12, 1994 | accessdate=May 30, 2022 | pages=F3}} Mario Tarradell of ''[[The Miami Herald]]'' similarly commended the band's humorous cuts such as "Redneck Martians Stole My Baby" and "Slaw", comparing the band favorably to [[Confederate Railroad]].{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/638287247/ | title=Hank Flamingo tracks hard-driving, offbeat | work=[[The Miami Herald]] | date=May 6, 1994 | accessdate=May 30, 2022 | pages=12G}} Hank Flamingo disbanded after only one album, and Trent Summar founded another band known as [[Trent Summar & The New Row Mob]], which also included former Hank Flamingo guitarist Philip Wallace. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Hank Flamingo'' | * Release date: February 1, 1994 * Label: [[Giant Records (Warner)|Giant Records]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Year ! style="width:10em;"| Single |- | 1993 ! scope="row"| "Baby It's You" |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! Year ! style="width:10em;"| Video !
